name: Takaya Shrine
short_description: Famous as the 'Torii in the Sky' with breathtaking views.
description: Located at the summit of Mt. Inazumi, this shrine features a torii gate that frames a spectacular view of the Seto Inland Sea and the city below. The steep climb is rewarded with one of the most photogenic vistas in Shikoku, often compared to a gateway to heaven.

name: Mt. Shiude
short_description: A stunning hilltop famous for cherry blossoms and island views.
description: This mountain offers a panoramic view of the Seto Inland Sea's many islands. It is particularly famous in spring when wild cherry blossoms frame the blue sea and sky. Even outside of spring, the view of the archipelago is serene and unmatched.

name: Chichibugahama Beach
short_description: Japan's answer to the Uyuni Salt Flat.
description: A long beach that creates perfect mirror reflections in the tide pools at low tide, especially during sunset. While it has gained popularity on social media, it remains a quiet seaside spot on weekdays where you can capture magical silhouette photos.

name: Nakayama Senmaida
short_description: Picturesque terraced rice fields on an island.
description: Over 800 rice paddies are carved into the hills of Shodoshima. The landscape changes with the seasons, from water-filled mirrors in spring to lush green in summer and golden ears in autumn. It hosts a traditional Kabuki stage and an insect-repelling torch festival.

name: Shodoshima Olive Park
short_description: A Mediterranean landscape with a white windmill.
description: Shodoshima is the birthplace of olive cultivation in Japan. This park features a Greek-style windmill and olive groves overlooking the sea. Visitors can rent broomsticks to recreate scenes from 'Kiki's Delivery Service,' which was filmed on the island.

name: Honjima (Shiwaku Islands)
short_description: Former base of the Shiwaku Navy with a preserved townscape.
description: Unlike the art-focused Naoshima, Honjima is steeped in maritime history. The Kasashima area preserves the beautiful Edo-period residences of the Shiwaku Navy carpenters. It is quiet, authentic, and offers a glimpse into the lives of the master shipbuilders who once ruled these waters.

name: Ogijima
short_description: A maze-like village of cats and art.
description: A small island with a village built on a steep slope, creating a labyrinth of narrow alleys. It is inhabited by a large population of friendly cats and features various contemporary art installations. The lighthouse at the island's tip is made of granite and is very picturesque.

name: Marugame Castle
short_description: Features the highest stone walls in Japan and an original keep.
description: One of only 12 original castle keeps remaining in Japan. While the keep itself is small, the massive, tiered stone walls are the highest in the country and incredibly impressive. The view from the top offers a commanding panorama of the Seto Ohashi Bridge.

name: Okubo-ji Temple
short_description: The final 88th temple of the Shikoku Pilgrimage.
description: Nestled in the mountains, this is the 'finishing' temple where pilgrims complete their journey and leave their walking sticks. The atmosphere is filled with a sense of completion and relief. It is also a famous spot for autumn foliage.

name: Negoro-ji Temple
short_description: Mountain temple known for the legend of the Ushi-oni demon.
description: Hidden in the forests of the Goshikidai plateau, this atmospheric temple is surrounded by momiji (maple) trees, making it stunning in autumn. It is famous for the legend of the Ushi-oni (ox-demon) that once terrorized the area; a statue of the creature stands near the entrance.

name: Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum
short_description: The preserved studio and home of the famous sculptor.
description: Located where Isamu Noguchi set up his studio to work with local granite. The museum preserves his working atmosphere, displaying 150 unfinished stone sculptures exactly as he left them. Tours are by appointment only (postcard reservation required), keeping it very exclusive.

name: Kinashi Bonsai Village
short_description: The largest bonsai production area in Japan.
description: Takamatsu produces about 80% of Japan's pine bonsai. In this neighborhood, fields are filled with miniature trees instead of crops. Many nurseries allow visitors to walk through and purchase bonsai. It is a quiet, unique landscape dedicated to a centuries-old art form.

name: Wakimachi Udatsu Street
short_description: A historic street of indigo merchants featuring 'Udatsu' firewalls.
description: This preserved street features Edo-period merchant houses with distinct 'Udatsu' wings on the roofs, a symbol of wealth. The area was a center for indigo trading. It remains a living town with indigo dyeing workshops and cafes inside the historic buildings.

name: Ochiai Village
short_description: A traditional hamlet clinging to a steep mountainside.
description: Located in the deep Iya Valley, this village consists of farmhouses built on a precipitous slope, connected by winding paths. It is a designated preservation district that retains the landscape of ancient Japan. A viewpoint on the opposite side of the valley offers a stunning panoramic look at the settlement.

name: Oku-Iya Niju Kazurabashi
short_description: The wilder, double vine bridges deep in the Iya Valley.
description: Far deeper in the mountains than the main Kazurabashi, these two 'husband and wife' vine bridges offer a more authentic and secluded experience. Visitors can pull themselves across the river in a small wooden cart called 'Yaen' (Wild Monkey).

name: Oboke Gorge
short_description: A dramatic gorge with jagged crystalline schist rocks.
description: The Yoshino River cuts through the mountains here, creating a ravine with unique rock formations that look like sculptures. Sightseeing boats offer a gentle ride to view the geological formations up close. The water is often a striking turquoise color.

name: Shosan-ji Temple
short_description: Mountain temple known as a 'pilgrim tumble' for its steep approach.
description: Temple 12 of the pilgrimage is one of the most difficult to reach on foot, located high on a mountain. The ancient cedar trees (some over 800 years old) and the cool mountain air give it a profound spiritual atmosphere distinct from the city temples.

name: Awa Jurobe Yashiki
short_description: A museum and theater for traditional Awa puppet puppetry.
description: Tokushima is famous for Bunraku puppetry. This residence of a former samurai (who sacrificed himself for his master) now serves as a theater where you can watch daily performances of Awa Ningyo Joruri. It is a more intimate experience than the National Bunraku Theatre.

name: Cape Kamota
short_description: The easternmost point of Shikoku with wild coastal views.
description: A remote cape offering sweeping views of the Kii Channel. It is known as a nesting ground for sea turtles. The distinctive lighthouse and the rugged, wind-swept landscape make it a perfect spot for solitude and nature appreciation.

name: Tebajima
short_description: A tiny island with no cars and preserved nature.
description: A 15-minute boat ride from Mugi Port, this island has no cars. The village features unique wooden walls to protect against sea spray. A walking path circles the island through primitive forests and along the rocky coast. It is a time capsule of island life.

name: Oahiko Shrine
short_description: The highest ranking shrine in Awa province.
description: Located at the base of Mt. Otani, this shrine has a magnificent camphor tree (over 1,000 years old). It is historically linked to the nearby Bando POW camp, where German prisoners of war built the 'German Bridge' within the shrine grounds during WWI.

name: Otani Pottery Village
short_description: Home of the massive Otani-yaki indigo dyeing jars.
description: This village produces the largest ceramic wares in Japan, traditionally used for indigo dyeing and lotus water lilies. Visitors can see the climbing kilns and try their hand at the pottery wheel. The scale of the pottery here is unlike anywhere else.

name: Hyoutan Island Cruise
short_description: A relaxing boat tour around the river island city center.
description: Central Tokushima City is located on an island shaped like a gourd (hyoutan). Small boats offer a cheap and scenic cruise around the city's waterways, passing under bridges and offering a unique perspective of the Awa Odori city.

name: Ryozen-ji Temple
short_description: The starting point of the 88 Temple Pilgrimage.
description: As Temple 1, this is where pilgrims purchase their white vestments and sedge hats. The grounds are beautiful with a koi pond and pagoda. Even if not doing the full pilgrimage, visiting here offers a glimpse into the beginning of the spiritual journey.

name: Yasui Valley
short_description: The ultimate spot to experience 'Niyodo Blue' water.
description: A ravine along a tributary of the Niyodo River where the water is famously clear and blue. The 'Suishobuchi' (Crystal Abyss) changes color depending on the light. It is less developed than other gorges, offering a pristine connection with nature.

name: Kashiwajima Island
short_description: Tropical paradise with boats that appear to float on air.
description: Located at the far southwest tip of Shikoku, this island is connected by a bridge. The water is so transparent that boats look like they are flying. It is a top-class diving spot with coral reefs and over 1,000 species of fish.

name: Monet's Garden Marmottan
short_description: The only replica garden authorized by the Monet Foundation.
description: This stunning garden faithfully recreates Claude Monet's garden in Giverny, France. It includes the famous water lily pond (with blue water lilies that actually bloom here, unlike in France) and a flower garden that bursts with color. It is a surreal slice of French Impressionism in rural Japan.

name: Yusuhara Town
short_description: A mountain town filled with Kengo Kuma architecture.
description: Renowned architect Kengo Kuma designed several buildings here using local cedar, including the 'Library Above the Clouds' and a wooden bridge gallery. The town itself is a hidden gem of modern design blending seamlessly with traditional mountain culture.

name: Hirome Market
short_description: A lively indoor market where you share tables with locals.
description: This collection of food stalls offers the best of Kochi soul food, especially Katsuo no Tataki (seared bonito). The seating is communal, and it is famous for its friendly, drinking culture where locals and tourists mix freely from midday onwards.

name: Kochi Sunday Market
short_description: A massive street market held every Sunday for 300 years.
description: Stretching for over 1km towards Kochi Castle, this market features hundreds of stalls selling local vegetables, citrus, knives, and street food. It is one of the oldest and largest open-air markets in Japan, bursting with local color and flavor.

name: Chikurin-ji Temple
short_description: A scholarly temple with a beautiful garden on Mt. Godaisan.
description: Temple 31 is known for its five-story pagoda and a stunning garden designated as a National Place of Scenic Beauty. It feels like a university of Buddhism and sits next to the Makino Botanical Garden, making for a perfect combined visit.

name: Kiragawa Preservation District
short_description: Townscape with white walls and 'water-draining' tiles.
description: This town features unique Tosa-style architecture designed to withstand typhoons, including 'water-draining tiles' on white plaster walls. It was once a charcoal trading hub. The streetscape is incredibly preserved and offers a stark contrast to the wild coast nearby.

name: Cape Muroto
short_description: A UNESCO Global Geopark with sub-tropical vegetation.
description: The tip of the V-shaped island, this cape features uplifted rocks and wild Pacific waves. It is home to Mikurodo Cave, where Kobo Daishi is said to have achieved enlightenment. The vegetation is distinctively sub-tropical, with wild hibiscus and prickly pear cactus.

name: Sada Chinka Bridge
short_description: The longest submersible bridge on the Shimanto River.
description: The Shimanto River is known for these 'chinka bashi' - bridges designed without rails to sink during floods. Crossing this low, narrow bridge by bicycle or on foot offers a thrilling connection to the river, known as 'Japan's last clear stream.'

name: Kaiyodo Hobby Museum Shimanto
short_description: A surreal figure museum in a retired elementary school.
description: Located deep in the mountains, this museum displays thousands of figurines (anime, animals, dinosaurs) made by the world-famous Kaiyodo company. The contrast between the remote rural setting and the pop-culture exhibits is fascinating and bizarre.

name: Sakawa Town
short_description: A brewing town with white-walled warehouses.
description: Home to the Tsukasabotan brewery, this town has a rich history of botany and sake. The streets are lined with traditional white-walled storehouses. It is the hometown of Dr. Tomitaro Makino, the father of Japanese botany, and features charming retro Western-style buildings.

name: Ryugado Cave
short_description: One of Japan's three best limestone caves.
description: A massive cave system inhabited since ancient times (yayoi pottery is embedded in the stalactites). The 'Adventure Course' allows visitors to crawl through narrow gaps and climb with headlights (reservation required), offering a real spelunking experience.

name: Garyu Sanso
short_description: A masterful villa that embodies 'Wabi-Sabi' aesthetics.
description: Perched on a cliff overlooking the Hiji River, this villa looks like a floating ship. Every detail of the architecture is symbolic and exquisite, designed to harmonize with nature and the moon. It is often cited by architects as one of the finest examples of Japanese tea house architecture.

name: Ozu Castle
short_description: A castle authentically reconstructed using traditional wood joinery.
description: Unlike many concrete reconstructions, this castle was rebuilt using traditional timber methods and documents. It offers a rare 'Castle Stay' experience where guests can rent the entire keep for the night. The view over the town and river is commanding.

name: Uchiko Preservation District
short_description: A town built on wealth from Japan wax and paper.
description: This street features grand merchant houses from the Meiji period, built with wealth from vegetable wax production. The Uchiko-za is a fully operational traditional Kabuki theater that visitors can explore, including the trapdoors and revolving stage.

name: Shikoku Karst
short_description: A rolling highland plateau dotted with white limestone.
description: Located at an altitude of 1,400m, this is the Switzerland of Shikoku. White limestone rocks dot the green grassy hills like sheep. It offers cool air in summer, starry skies at night, and distant views of the Pacific Ocean.

name: Shimonada Station
short_description: An isolated station famous for its view of the sea.
description: Often featured in posters and anime (resembling the Spirited Away station), this unmanned station sits right on the water's edge. There is nothing to do here but sit on the bench and watch the sunset over the Seto Inland Sea, making it a pilgrimage for photographers.

name: Minetopia Besshi (Tonaru Zone)
short_description: The 'Machu Picchu of the East' hidden in the mountains.
description: The ruins of a massive copper mine located high in the mountains. The brick storages and theater ruins sit on steep stone walls, creating an ancient city vibe. It is often shrouded in mist, adding to the mysterious atmosphere.

name: Oyamazumi Shrine
short_description: Houses 80% of Japan's National Treasure samurai armor.
description: Located on Omishima island, this shrine was worshipped by samurai and pirates alike. The treasure hall contains an unbelievable collection of swords and armor worn by famous historical figures like Minamoto no Yoritomo and Tomoe Gozen. A 2,600-year-old camphor tree stands in the precinct.

name: Kirosan Observatory
short_description: The best viewpoint of the Shimanami Kaido bridges.
description: Designed by architect Kengo Kuma, the observatory itself is hidden in the ground to protect the landscape. The view of the Kurushima Kaikyo Bridge and the strong tidal currents below is breathtaking, especially at sunset.

name: Nametoko Valley
short_description: Famous for the Yukiwa Falls and natural water slides.
description: A canyon of granite smooth enough to slide down. The Yukiwa Falls is one of Japan's top 100 waterfalls. It is a popular spot for canyoning tours in summer, but offers beautiful, quiet hiking along the clear stream in other seasons.

name: Nanrakuen Garden
short_description: The largest traditional Japanese garden in Shikoku.
description: This vast pond-stroll garden draws on the landscapes of the surrounding mountains and sea. It is particularly stunning during the iris season (May-June). Despite its size and beauty, it sees far fewer foreign tourists than Ritsurin Garden.

name: Tobe Pottery Village
short_description: A town dedicated to thick, blue-and-white porcelain.
description: Tobeyaki is known for its durability and distinct indigo designs. The town is dotted with potteries and a 'Ceramic Road' where ceramic plates are embedded in the pavement. Visitors can paint their own dishes at the Togei Sosakukan.

name: Isaniwa Shrine
short_description: A rare Hachiman-zukuri style shrine overlooking Dogo Onsen.
description: Climb the 135 stone steps near Dogo Onsen station to find this vermillion masterpiece. It is one of only three shrines in Japan sharing this specific architectural style with Iwashimizu Hachimangu in Kyoto. It offers a quiet, spiritual break from the busy onsen town below.

name: Yusumizugaura Terraced Fields
short_description: steep stone-walled fields rising from the sea.
description: Known as 'Cultivating the way to heaven,' these potato and rice fields are built on an incredibly steep slope facing the Uwa Sea. The stone walls are a testament to the hard labor of the local farmers. The view of the sunset over the ocean from the top is unforgettable.
